content.title: Brugada Syndrome
content.summary: Brugada syndrome is an inherited cardiac channelopathy characterized by distinctive coved-type ST elevation in right precordial leads (V1-V3) and increased risk of ventricular fibrillation and sudden cardiac death, typically occurring during rest or sleep. It results from loss-of-function mutations in cardiac sodium channel genes (SCN5A in ~25%).
key_points: Type 1 (coved) ECG pattern diagnostic: ≥2mm J-point elevation with coved ST-segment and negative T-wave in V1-V3
Type 2/3 patterns (saddleback) are suggestive but not diagnostic; require provocation testing
SCN5A mutations found in ~25% of cases; autosomal dominant inheritance
Risk factors: male sex, fever, sodium channel blockers, excessive alcohol, vagal states
ICD indicated for survivors of SCA or documented spontaneous sustained VT
Quinidine and isoproterenol for electrical storm; catheter ablation of epicardial substrate emerging
content.statement: Brugada syndrome is a major cause of sudden cardiac death in young adults with structurally normal hearts. Diagnosis requires recognition of the characteristic Type 1 ECG pattern (spontaneous or drug-induced), and risk stratification guides ICD implantation decisions. Fever can unmask the pattern and trigger arrhythmias.

explanation.intuition: Loss-of-function sodium channel mutations reduce INa current in the right ventricular outflow tract epicardium, where Ito (transient outward potassium current) is prominent. This creates a transmural voltage gradient (phase 2 reentry substrate) and the characteristic ST elevation on surface ECG. The resulting early repolarization in epicardium can trigger ventricular fibrillation.
explanation.key_insight: The Type 1 (coved) pattern is diagnostic; Types 2 and 3 (saddleback) require sodium channel blocker provocation to convert to Type 1 for diagnosis. Events typically occur at rest, during sleep, or with vagal enhancement (after large meals). Fever is a major trigger that can both unmask the pattern and precipitate arrhythmias.
explanation.technical_details: Diagnostic criteria require Type 1 pattern in ≥1 right precordial lead (V1-V3) positioned in standard or high (2nd-3rd intercostal) position, either spontaneous or after provocation with sodium channel blockers (ajmaline, flecainide, procainamide). High lead placement increases sensitivity.

definitions_glossary.brugada_syndrome: Inherited sodium channelopathy with characteristic Type 1 ECG pattern and risk of sudden cardiac death from VF
definitions_glossary.type1_brugada_pattern: Coved ST elevation ≥2mm in V1-V3 with negative T-wave; diagnostic pattern
definitions_glossary.type2_brugada_pattern: Saddleback ST elevation ≥0.5mm in V1-V3 with positive/biphasic T-wave; requires conversion
definitions_glossary.scn5a: Gene encoding cardiac sodium channel alpha subunit; mutated in ~25% of Brugada syndrome
definitions_glossary.sodium_channel_provocation: Ajmaline, flecainide, or procainamide challenge to unmask Brugada pattern
definitions_glossary.phase2_reentry: Mechanism of VF in Brugada from transmural dispersion of repolarization
definitions_glossary.right_ventricular_outflow_tract: RVOT is the substrate location for Brugada arrhythmogenesis
definitions_glossary.epicardial_ablation: Catheter ablation of arrhythmogenic substrate in RVOT epicardium
definitions_glossary.fever_induced_brugada: Fever unmasks ECG pattern and triggers arrhythmias; aggressive antipyretics required
definitions_glossary.quinidine: Ito blocker that normalizes ECG and reduces arrhythmia burden in Brugada
definitions_glossary.isoproterenol: Beta-agonist used acutely for electrical storm; increases ICaL and suppresses arrhythmias
definitions_glossary.implantable_cardioverter_defibrillator: ICD is only proven therapy to prevent SCD; indicated for survivors of arrest

pathophysiology.mechanism: SCN5A loss-of-function mutations reduce sodium current (INa), predominantly affecting the RVOT epicardium where transient outward potassium current (Ito) is prominent. Reduced INa with unopposed Ito causes early repolarization of epicardium relative to endocardium, creating transmural voltage gradient manifesting as ST elevation. Phase 2 reentry from this dispersion triggers VF.
key_pathways: SCN5A mutation → reduced INa → loss of action potential dome in epicardium
Prominent Ito in RVOT epicardium → early repolarization
Transmural voltage gradient → ST elevation on ECG
Dispersion of repolarization → phase 2 reentry → VF
pathophysiology.clinical_significance: Leading cause of sudden death in young adults with structurally normal hearts in Southeast Asia (SUNDS). Male predominance (8:1) due to higher testosterone levels enhancing Ito.

type1_coved.diagnosis: Diagnostic of Brugada syndrome if spontaneous or provoked

type2_saddleback.diagnosis: Suggestive; requires provocation to convert to Type 1

provocation_testing.contraindications: Baseline Type 1 pattern, unstable patient, severe conduction disease

quinidine.mechanism: Ito blocker that normalizes repolarization gradient
quinidine.indication: ICD with frequent shocks, electrical storm, patients declining ICD
quinidine.dosing: Titrate to therapeutic level; QTc monitoring required

isoproterenol.mechanism: Increases ICaL; restores dome; suppresses VF

catheter_ablation.outcomes: Eliminates Type 1 pattern and arrhythmias in 90%+

trigger_avoidance: Avoid sodium channel blockers, cocaine, excessive alcohol
Avoid large meals that increase vagal tone

altLabel: Right Bundle Branch Block with ST Elevation
skos.definition: An inherited cardiac channelopathy characterized by coved ST-segment elevation in right precordial leads and increased risk of ventricular fibrillation and sudden cardiac death

learning_objectives: Recognize Type 1, 2, and 3 Brugada ECG patterns
Describe the pathophysiology of phase 2 reentry in Brugada syndrome
Apply risk stratification to guide ICD implantation decisions
Manage acute electrical storm with isoproterenol
Counsel patients on trigger avoidance including fever management
clinical_pearls: Only Type 1 (coved) pattern is diagnostic; saddleback requires provocation
Fever is a major trigger - treat aggressively with antipyretics
Events occur at rest/sleep, not with exercise (unlike LQTS type 1)
Male predominance 8:1 due to testosterone enhancing Ito current
High lead placement (2nd-3rd ICS) increases ECG sensitivity
25% have identifiable SCN5A mutation; cascade screening for families
common_misconceptions: All Brugada patients need ICD (only survivors of arrest or with sustained VT)
Amiodarone is useful (actually may worsen; use quinidine or isoproterenol)
Saddleback pattern is diagnostic (only coved Type 1 is diagnostic)
